(Photo: Kevin Winter, Getty Images) 
When Mary Tyler Moore created a character that revolutionized the way we view single career women, she also gave her an incredible best friend in Valerie Harper's Rhoda Morgenstern. 
Moore died on Wednesday at age 80 , and now Harper, 77, has paid tribute to her Mary Tyler Moore Show co-star she called a "soulmate" and "co-pilot" with a heartfelt statement to People . 
"Last week, to prepare me, I was kindly warned by Mary Tyler Moore’s dear husband, Dr. Robert Levine, that she was in the very last stages of life," Harper said. "But still I cannot stop the emotions I’m experiencing, since she was my acting colleague, my sister/soulmate, and above all, ONE HELL OF A GIRLFRIEND!" Celebrate Mary Tyler Moore with these TV specials and marathons 
"Working together we knew each other so well we could anticipate each other’s moods, ever ready to engage and KNOW there would be an appropriate response from Mary," Harper added. 
"I will always feel privileged and honored with the amount of quality time I was able to spend with Mary." 
Harper also tweeted her thoughts after the news of Moore's death broke. To The World I'll miss you "Mair."I will always be your co-pilot. I will always love you, darling Mary Tyler Moore. — Valerie Harper (@ValerieHarper) January 26, 2017 Facebook Posted! A link has been posted to your Facebook feed. Actress Mary Tyler Moore died Wednesday at 80, her longtime publicist, Mara Buxbaum confirmed to USA TODAY. Kevin Winter, Getty Images Moore broke out playing housewife Laura Petrie on CBS' 'The Dick Van Dyke Show' from 1961-66. Calvada Productions, Inc. All Rights Reserved. Moore proved herself to be the comic equal to Van Dyke, making for perfect sitcom chemistry. ASSOCIATED PRESS Moore won two Emmys for her work on 'The Dick Van Dyke Show.' A&E/PHOTOFEST Less than a decade later, it would be Mary Tyler Moore's name in the title of the show. Courtesy of Pioneers of Television Fullscreen Her character, 30-year-old Mary Richards, applied for a secretarial job at a Minneapolis TV station but instead wound up an associate producer. She would frequently wind up caught between boss Lou Grant (Ed Asner, left) and pompous anchorman Ted Baxter (Ted Knight). XXX CBS 'The Mary Tyler Moore Show' will always be associated with one pose: Mary throwing her hat in the air in the opening credits. In 1996, Moore re-enacted it in front of the house where her character rented an apartment. CHERYL A. MEYER, Associated Press The Mary Tyler Moore pose even earned its own statue on display at theMinneapolis Visitor Information center. Meet Minneapolis Fullscreen 'The Mary Tyler Moore Show' was an Emmy favorite, earning 29 Emmys by the time it signed off the air in 1977. That record wouldn't be broken until 2002, when 'Frasier' won its 30th trophy. Here, stars Ed Asner, Betty White, Moore and Ted Knight celebrate their sweep of the comedy acting prizes at the 1976 Primetime Emmys. Reed Saxon, AP The 'Mary Tyler Moore' cast, seen together in a 1975 set photo. (From left: White, Knight, Georgia Engel, Gavin MacLeod, Moore and Asner) CBS Photo Archive, Getty Images Fullscreen The cast of 'The Mary Tyler Moore Show' reunited for an episode of TV Land's 'Hot in Cleveland' in 2012. Moore made a pair of appearances on the show featuring her old co-star Betty White. (From left; White, Valerie Harper, Ed Asner, Mary Tyler Moore, Gavin MacLeod, Cloris Leachman and Georgia Engel) Anonymous, AP Moore and White also teamed up on the Emmy stage in 2008 to present Tina Fey with an award. Robert Hanashiro, USA TODAY Moore is closely associated with co-star Valerie Harper, right, who played her best friend Rhoda Morgenstern and later got her own spifnoff. Decades later, the actresses reprised their roles in the TV movie 'Mary and Rhoda.' Robert Deutsch, USA TODAY Moore frequently collaborated with Dick Van Dyke as well. He presented her with her lifetime achievement honor at the 2012 Screen Actors Guild Awards. Robert Hanashiro, USA TODAY Moore also earned an Oscar nomination and a Golden Globe for best actress in 1980's 'Ordinary People,' alongside a young Timothy Hutton. PARAMOUNT PICTURES Fullscreen Another role near and dear to Moore's heart: advocating for people with diabetes, especially children. She was diagnosed with Type 1 diabetes at age 33. Here, she's seen testifying on behalf of juvenile diabetes research in 2001 at a Senate Government Affairs Committee alongside actor Kevin Kline, left, and former astronaut James Lovell. DENNIS COOK, Associated Press Flowers sit on actress Mary Tyler Moore's Hollywood Walk of Fame star on Jan. 25, 2017 in Hollywood, California. Mary Tyler Moore died on Wednesday at a Greenwich, Connecticut hospital. She was 80 years old. Justin Sullivan, Getty Images Like this topic? You may also like these photo galleries: Replay
